2025-02-27|I get why nationalists and so.fullText:
I get why nationalists and socialists oppose empire. Socialists think the US is exploiting the world, while nationalists think the US is exploited by the world. 

And both actually have a point, on different dimensions, if you look through it from their respective lenses:

However, what's missing is the center-left and center-right defense of American Empire. In part this is because even the existence of this empire is not acknowledged. Despite having 750 military bases and the headquarters of the UN in New York, there is the pretense that this all somehow happened by accident.

But becoming global #1 in every category does not happen by accident. Wertheim's book documents exactly how and when the decision was made to seek empire: in 1940, after the fall of France, when the US realized that if they didn't build an empire then the Nazis (or, later, the Soviets) would.

However, unlike past empires, American Empire is a hidden empire — as Daniel Immerwahr points out. Unlike the British Empire, it's not referred to in explicitly imperial terms, even if countries are expected to obey DC and pay tribute by buying Treasuries. 

Like the Soviet Empire, it's ideological yet invisible. And like the B2 Stealth Bomber, enormous resources were spent obscuring the empire of democracy, like they were for the empire of communism.

Anyway, this conversation is tricky because if you say "empire" then people instantly assume you're saying "empire is bad."

But it's not always bad. Sometimes it's almost self-defense. Because power abhors a vacuum — and if you do decide not to play for world domination, you may well be dominated by the one who does.

And that's the logic of empire.

This was understood generations ago. But today, neither left nor right fully appreciates what it took to build American empire. They just inherited it. They don't understand it.

Among other things, the far left doesn't realize that it required capitalism and trade. The nationalist right doesn't realize that it required democracy and allies.

Combining these was the only way to build the multibillion-person global trade union that underpins the US dollar. You couldn't do that with 77M Trump voters or 75M Democrats alone. You need trade partners, you need allies.

Otherwise, when you print $6T (as the US did from 2020-2022) it's spread not across 6B+ people worldwide but just ~330M Americans. Because inflation is taxation, that's a 95% drop in the effective tax base. You go from printing $1000/head to $20000/head, with all the obvious consequences.

Anyway, I completely understand why many US factions are tired of these abstractions. Because this concrete empire doesn't seem to be working for them. What isn't being considered is that things may get even worse, at least temporarily, if empire is retired.

I guess we'll see what happens.

2025-02-27|Here's how USDC launched. In.fullText:
Here's how USDC launched.

In mid-2018, Circle had an audited smart contract.
But they'd exited the exchange business in 2016.
Coinbase, meanwhile, had capital & distribution.
So I flew to Boston and proposed a deal.
We set up the CENTRE consortium with Circle.
And capitalized it with $25M in corporate funds.

The underlying idea behind USDC was simple.
Back one USDC with one USD in a bank account.
Just do 1:1 redemption.
No order book, no conversion risk, no games.
No volatile plutonium underlying a stablecoin.
Just like withdrawing a dollar from an ATM...
You withdraw a dollar to the blockchain.

But executing that simple idea wasn't that easy.
We needed a banking partner to hold the USD.
And we needed to code the smart contract integration.
Both nontrivial regulatory and security problems.
Especially in 2018.

However, with two brilliant engineers (@maksim_s @mihar), one resourceful BD lead (@JimMigdal), and a PM with the soul of an artist (@js_horne) — we got it done.

From $0 to $1.
And then to $1B+ in interest income.
Within about five years.

Pretty awesome partnership with @jerallaire and his Circle team.

2024-03-17|COUNTRIES LIKE COMPANIES Reg.fullText:
COUNTRIES LIKE COMPANIES

Regarding trade imbalances with a fixed currency:

1) I don’t believe in the oft-repeated Keynesian idea that “governments aren’t households/companies so they don’t need to balance their budget.”

2) For one thing, the largest companies are now bigger and wealthier than all but the largest governments, and if we agree that a company like Apple needs to balance its books then so does at least 50% of the UN.

3) For another thing, only the very largest and most powerful states can print/counterfeit money and kill people without reprisal, which is the primary way they differ from households, and this relative power imbalance is falling every day. On many dimensions the CEO of Meta is more powerful than many heads of state.

4) So, if companies need to manage their “trade imbalances” over the long run by producing more than they consume, so will countries. A company that spends more than it earns and runs out of cash gets external investors or is shut down/acquired. 

5) Similarly a country that runs out of money by importing much more than it exports (“trade imbalance”) will need external help of some kind or get “acquired” by a bigger country. This already exists today when there is a balance-of-payments crisis, whether the party stepping in is IMF or Belt and Road.

There will probably be more options in the world to come (perhaps selling territory again as per Alaska and Louisiana Purchase), but the point is there is no free lunch — you can’t import more valuable goods than you export indefinitely without paying for it somehow.

2024-03-17|HYPERDEFLATION > SAVINGS > EQ.fullText:
HYPERDEFLATION > SAVINGS > EQUITY > DEBT

In a Bitcoin-backed economy, the hypothetical debt-deflation issues would be avoided by (a) minimizing debt and (b) funding more things with savings and equity as well as (c) leaning into technological hyperdeflation of costs.

To take those points in turn:

1) We have way too much debt in society. At the individual level it’s student loans, 30 year mortgages, credit cards, and even AfterPay. At the state level it’s dysfunctional municipal debt, constant bond issuance, and soaring interest payments.

This world is ending. As Dalio has also discussed, the sovereign debt crises are beginning and the debt deleveraging is coming. Many debts will face hard default because they won’t be paid. Others will experience soft default where a sovereign prints away the debt, satisfying it in nominal but not real terms.

But overall, many who owe money won’t pay, and many who think they are owed money won’t be getting paid. It may be a debt jubilee of a very messy kind, and it’ll mean long-term skepticism towards debt.

2) If you zoom out, many faith traditions from Christianity to Islam to Judaism have had taboos against usury. Yet somehow interest rates have recently been put at the very center of what was once Western civilization, as everyone fixates on the Fed’s rate gyrations.

Of course, you can’t completely remove the concept of interest rates — they are a power user tool to compare different kinds of investments — but you can radically reduce the emphasis on them by prioritizing technological hyperdeflation of cost over savings, savings over equity financing, and equity over debt — in that order.

3) Why put technological hyperdeflation of cost as first priority? Well, in the absence of the Fed monkeying around with things, we should be able to see that the real prices for things decline as technology improves. Eg with better tech we use fewer joules of energy to produce a smartphone or a tomato. So, sharply reducing real costs with tech is the first priority.

4) Why savings over equity as second priority? Well, most things shouldn’t need to be financed with external parties. You just save up and buy them yourself. And don’t buy till you need them. But the focus on technological hyperdeflation means real cost keeps coming down — so savings can be viably used to buy more things.

5) Then why equity over debt as third resort? Equity is how tech does financing and it is good for ambitious things and people. It’s far more tolerant of uncertainty than debt and is more suited to our time of ultra-high volatility. It’s also suitable only for high potential people and projects, as opposed to our current practice of saddling everyone with debt.

6) Finally, debt is an absolute last resort for financing. It will be frowned upon in the next generation after the upcoming debt deleveraging. Debt should just be an extremely uncommon thing, used only by power users in highly certain circumstances.

7) And how do you save at scale then, if governments aren’t issuing bonds? Ideally, you invest in Bitcoin. In practice, for technical reasons not everyone will be able to hold BTC directly, but there will be enough who do that it’ll keep the global economy honest.

Bitcoin is the index asset of the entire technologically hyperdeflating economy. It’s like a combination of gold and Vanguard. It’s a simple “no op” which is valued in every country and which everything else is benchmarked against, as is already happening in the cryptoeconomy.

8) Finally, what about money for innovation? Yes, only really good investments will be worth risking the natural appreciation of your Bitcoin — but a state limited by Bitcoin is also far less able to jack up costs by uselessly NIMBYing new technologies, so the overall ability to innovate will be increased.

The Wild West era where a gold standard coincided with immense American technological innovation is the most obvious historical parallel.

2024-03-17|A few things: 1) The fees sh.fullText:
A few things:

1) The fees show the Bitcoin network is valuable enough that users are provably paying to use it. In that sense they are analogous to cash flows.

2) The BTC to the miners is a little bit like stock-based compensation for employees. If you give employees stock, they can sell it, and that's an expense that can reduce the price of your stock. But it's also an expense that many high-flying companies have.

3) I agree with your implicit point, that proof-of-stake doesn't have the same semi-obligate downward price pressure. However, proof-of-stake also has weak subjectivity issues unlike proof-of-work. I'm not a maximalist and see room for both.

4) At 50000 feet, if you had a social network that made ~$0 per year in 2010 and $1B/year in 2024, it'd be a fairly fast growing company. So too for a currency network. 

5) In general: analogies like this are like the analogy between paper documents and digital documents. They break down if you push on them too hard. But they are meant to rebut the idea that these networks are just pet rocks without any economic substance.

6) I think there is way more substance here than just the direct fees (what's the value of seizure resistance, or a global historical record and notary public?). But at least it knocks down one of the lazier Wall Street vest guy arguments.

9) YES, THERE ARE MANY COUNTERARGUMENTS

- Isn't all the ETF Bitcoin custodial?

- Doesn't Bitcoin have limited onchain scalability?
- Isn't Bitcoin limited in terms of its privacy?

The fundamental question is whether the bad people behind the Fed can outsmart the good people in Bitcoin. And thus far, the Network has outpaced the State.

2024-01-11|HISTORY IS RUNNING IN REVERSE.fullText:
HISTORY IS RUNNING IN REVERSE

The Bitcoin ETF is the spiritual reversal of Executive Order 6102. Back in 1935, they seized the gold. But now, digital gold is back.

Ninety years ago, FDR and his fellow travelers rode the 20th century arc of centralization. The chokepoints of then-new technologies for mass media and mass production allowed them to gain control over the population, recruit top talent for their "Brain Trust", and seize the gold after a series of epic legal battles[1].

Those gold clause cases are forgotten today, but received as much contemporary coverage as 9/11 or the Moon Landing. They were the most important issue in the country, receiving far more coverage than seemingly comparable Supreme Court decisions like Roe vs Wade. Why?[2]

The reason is that the transition from a gold-backed to fiat-backed system was comparable to a soft communist revolution, as the *visible* seizure of gold laid the groundwork for the *invisible* seizure of wealth via money printing.

And the classically trained judges at that time fully understood this. Justice McReynolds' then-famous dissent denounced the ruling in the harshest terms, noting that the "Constitution is gone" and the "dollar...may be 30c tomorrow, 10c the next day, and 1c the day following".[3]

McReynolds was right.

While the court was forced into a grudging institutional surrender by FDR's threat of court-packing[2], the gold clause case affected every economic decision-maker in the country, as it amounted to the US government explicitly defaulting on its bonds by seizing the assets of its citizens, laying the groundwork for the century of monetary debasement to come.[4]

Now all of that is unwinding. FDR's team could ride the wave of centralizing technology that built giant states around the world. But today, technology today favors *decentralization* — personal computers, end-to-end encryption, mobile phones, and of course cryptocurrency [5]. 

Thus, top talent isn't being pulled into a government Brain Trust. It's being brain drained *out* of the US establishment. And as a consequence the epic legal battles are, on balance, going our way.

It's not just the DC Circuit case.[6] The ideological conflict between decentralization and centralization is reflected in the 3-2 vote for the Bitcoin ETF approval itself. Read Peirce's brilliant pro-liberty approval[7],  Crenshaw's dour denial[8], and Gensler's reluctant approval[9].

You'll see echos of the gold clause case, but in reverse. This time, it is the centralized state that is being forced into a grudging institutional surrender. And a surrender it is, as Crenshaw's dissent[8] makes clear: 

"...there is no primary regulator for the bitcoin spot markets. Spot bitcoin ETPs will be participating in an unregulated, fragmented, continuously traded, global free-for-all. Even if there were a primary regulator for this market, much of it could be beyond the reach of U.S. regulation..."

Let that sink in! This is what the US establishment truly fears: not Bitcoin as "fraud", but Bitcoin as freedom. They want to rule not just you but the world, so they're scared of the prospect of "a global free-for-all..beyond the reach of US regulation". And they know that any spot ETF will bid up the price of self-custodied Bitcoin outside their control[10], as Satoshi intended.

So: since FDR's seizure of gold, our lives have revolved around the centralized state rather than the decentralized market. The state has had control for so long we've forgotten what freedom is like. But now gold is slipping out of their hands, and back into yours.

History is running in reverse.

So: are there more aviation incidents, is social media amplifying rare events, or is it all just our imagination?

2023-12-13|ANALYSIS OF COMPETING HYPOTHE.fullText:
ANALYSIS OF COMPETING HYPOTHESES

I appreciate this post by @robbensinger because it reminds me of a CIA technique called the "Analysis of Competing Hypotheses."

The concept is documented at length in Chapter 8 of Heuer's 1999 book on the Psychology of Intelligence Analysis[1]. But the idea is relatively simple: when smart people differ, it's often due to a difference in premises that you can tease out.

The figure below is an example[2] for a corporation arguing about the root cause of why competitors keep beating their bids very narrowly and on price.

1) You first put the hypotheses across the top — are hackers stealing commercial information in general, are specific insiders selling commercial information, or have listening devices been placed in the office[3]?

2) Then you put the observed facts down the side — you're seeing that quotes are consistently and narrowly beaten on price, that the leaks are from all departments, and so on.

3) Finally, you score each observation as consistent or inconsistent with the hypothesis. For example, if you observed that the "leaked information is from all departments" that would be inconsistent with a "specific insider is selling commercial information", because the insider wouldn't know about all departments.

4) While the Analysis of Competing Hypotheses is overkill for routine debugging, I find it helpful for getting at the root cause in complex situations where there are many hypotheses and observations floating around.

5) Seems like it might be useful to do this for AI, where intelligent people disagree on unarticulated premises. Perhaps the single biggest areas I disagree with the AI safety people on is the utility of appealing to a dysfunctional US government to regulate AI. This government causes existential risks (like funding the Wuhan lab and risking nuclear war with Russia), it doesn't mitigate them.

6) As such, I think technology work > policy work for just about anything, but particularly cutting edge areas where the state is either ignorant or hostile or both.
 
[1]: https://t.co/qV3cx7Xn4W
[2]: https://t.co/cYFvS415FG
[3]: The latter seems paranoid but would be a legitimate concern for semiconductor companies competing with China.

2023-12-12|THE NEW HOLY TRINITY A few m.fullText:
THE NEW HOLY TRINITY

A few miscellaneous observations on the foundations of what was once Western civilization.

1) The new holy trinity is both newer and older than you might think. Newer in the sense of being brand new moral premises on which to found (or deconstruct) a society. But older in the sense of going back many more decades than the 2010s.

2) The new holy trinity is also a set of moral premises that displaces earlier moral premises. Because the human mind can only recall so many commandments. Even 10 is kind of pushing it. 

So, for example, a society that says “thou shalt not lie” is different from a society that says “thou shalt not be racist.” What if stating the truth would be baselessly attacked as racist? Then you might not state the truth. 

And thus do the new moral premises displace the old. You get a society of liars, but at least they’re not “racist.”

A great example of this is the controversy over the drug BiDil.[1] Sure, the data showed it helped African Americans with heart failure. But wait — prescribing it would mean saying self-identified ancestry has some correlation with biology! And so the usual suspects got to protesting medical racism, harming the population they pretended to help. They may have lied about the data, but at least they weren’t “racist.”

3) Next — the new holy trinity has marched upwards for almost 100 years. See how these curves move up over decades, but with cyclic pauses every so often?[2]

Perhaps that’s just an artifact of the data analysis. Or perhaps that’s when conservatives think they’re “winning”, in those moments when there is a slight downturn in the chart. The pendulum is swinging, baby! The silent majority is asserting itself. And we are so back.

Actually — no. In retrospect, during those periods, wokism was just consolidating power for the next upward push. Like Lenin’s New Economic Policy, which was a head fake that lulled people to complacency before the next bout of communist insanity[3].

4) So: what could stop the multi-decadal rise of the new holy trinity? Well, a true change (rather than a head fake) would show woke terms drop off a cliff in usage, just as their Marxist equivalents did in the territories of the former Soviet Union after 1991.

After all, you didn’t hear too much about “class struggle”, “workers of the world”, or “comrades” after that ideology produced a calamitous imperial collapse.[4]

But that’s what it took to kill Soviet communism. Not a fake internal reform like the New Economic Policy, but an actual collapse.

Something to keep in mind…
[1]: https://t.co/FhSFEgBXUJ
[2]: https://t.co/hKEZL4JO5o
[3]: https://t.co/6lkEaOQOZT
[4]: https://t.co/oGJlbOPl96

2023-09-18|AI, e/acc, and decentralizati.fullText:
AI, e/acc, and decentralization

> e/acc bros are generally optimistic about tech... the one exception is a lot of us are nocoiners and fairly negative on crypto.  why is this?

Good topic. First, it's a bit more than just two camps. I think it's more like five, arranged in order of most to least statist.

1) AI risk: wants state to stop AGI
2) e/acc-c: is fine with centralized AI
3) e/acc-d: wants decentralized AI
4) Crypto: wants decentralized alternatives to web2
5) Bitcoin: wants total focus on decentralized alternative to Fed

The most important difference between these camps is *not* on the tech, but on the ideological values underneath. The key question is: how much do you trust Washington, DC?

1) AI riskers de facto trust it a lot, because they want to empower it to do "airstrikes on datacenters" (even after DC just aimlessly blew up the Middle East for 20 years). 

2) e/acc-c may not go that far, but they're willing to tolerate significant amounts of state failure to live in places like San Francisco.

3) e/acc-d is where some decentralization starts kicking in. They don't trust the SF city government, so they want to make radical moves to fix the city. They also don't fully trust centralized corporations, so they want to decentralize the models, as Llama 2 has done.

4) crypto is even more focused on decentralization, but in what they would call a pragmatic way. They'd argue that decentralization is a continuum, and that services that are more open than existing web2 backends are important to the way forward.

5) Bitcoin maximalism is not only focused on decentralization, they think everything besides Bitcoin is a distraction because it takes away attention from the most pressing issue of it all: the ultimate rugpull by the US government, the Fed's ongoing devaluation of the dollar.

The conflict that @mimi10v3 sees is between groups 1/2 and groups 3/4/5, but groups 2/3 are really quite distinct in their thinking. 

(You could in theory believe in both AGI apocalypse and Bitcoin apocalypse, but the nature of such things is that camps 1 and 5 have relatively little overlap, because camp 1 ends up advocating for powering up DC and while camp 5 ends up taking it away.)

My view is that the oncoming rush of AI regulations and ongoing real-cost-of-living increases will move more people into groups 3-5, the decentralization-focused groups. 

And it really all boils down to how much you trust DC.

2023-09-18|Yes, I get that this is the t.fullText:
Yes, I get that this is the theory. But a few thoughts.

1) First, the right way to proceed is to reduce the cost of living through technological innovation and sunsetting obsolete regulations. Financial manipulations can only get us so far. Interest rate changes won't structurally reduce the cost of (say) space flight.

2) Second, many people don't have ultra-flexible short-term debt where they can instantly respond to changes in rates. Many took on long-term debt before Dec 2021 given Powell and Yellen's repeated promises that rates would be kept low forever.

3) Third, individuals feel the rising costs imposed by both inflation and rate hikes at the same time. Their actual concern is rising cost-of-living.

4) Fourth, part of the goal of the rate hikes is as Powell said: to put people out of work. And if your income is $0 then everything is now very costly.

5) Finally, inflation reduces the cost of borrowing money because it eats into the real value of the amount owed and is typically good for the borrower. We are in a bad state right now, though where rates keep getting hiked to try to get them above official inflation. 

So many borrowers are dreading the date when they need to refinance, and many lenders are treading water till they can finally refinance.

https://t.co/XEHI0HX2bn

2023-09-15|This kind of thing has happen.fullText:
This kind of thing has happened before. People once spoke of Europe and Christendom, before they referred to America and the West.

That shift of the global center to America was a territorial shift, but it was also an ethnic, religious, political, and technological shift. As focus gradually moved from God to the State, the religious conception of “Christendom” declined and the quasi-geographical idea of “the West” gained traction as a way to delineate the borders of a community.

Today, the global center of mass has moved again. Just as it moved from the Old World to the New World, it’s moved from the physical America to the international Internet.

Of course, the Internet is the child of America, just as America was the child of the UK. But it’s becoming something different. A successor that exceeds its worthy progenitor.

2023-08-13|Like @SamoBurja, I appreciate.fullText:
Like @SamoBurja, I appreciate leaders who execute great turnarounds.

But in all of these cases these turnarounds were driven by competition. An alternative model, an exit, a competitive threat.

Not necessarily solely in the sense of “we are losing citizens to them via emigration”, though that was certainly a factor in the capitalist reforms of China and India.

But in the broader sense of “this alternative system is outcompeting us”. 

For example, the Meiji Restoration was driven by Japan’s technological backwardness relative to the Western powers, something they only became deeply aware of after Commodore Perry’s visit.

Realizing their weakness led them to change their government and build strength. Seeing the alternative is what spurred reform. No exits, no alternatives = no reforms.

2023-08-13|SATOSHI AND SATYA I agree wi.fullText:
SATOSHI AND SATYA

I agree with some of Samo’s other points in the thread — but exit amplifies voice.

1) It’s only because Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Singapore existed that Deng Xiaoping had a model to turn around China. 

All the Chinese people who wanted to leave the PRC told everyone that something was wrong. The military strength of tiny capitalist Taiwan was even becoming comparable to the PRC in 1978. Without the evidence that Chinese people could live better lives, a “capitalist roader” like Deng would never have taken power.

2) Similarly, it’s only because of Apple and Google that Satya Nadella had a model to turn around Microsoft. All the Microsoft customers who left for those companies told him something was wrong, and proved the case for a “cloud roader” to take power — leaning into cloud, mobile, and now even stealing a march on Google with AI.

3) But turnaround of this kind is extremely difficult and often doesn’t work. So for the individual with no realistic chance of taking power and executing a turnaround (or doing so as a group), like the millions of Chinese who weren’t Deng or the millions of customers that didn’t want to wait a decade for Ballmer to be replaced, the true vote against a failing regime is exit.

4) Sometimes the place these people are leaving fixes itself, and sometimes it doesn’t, but at least rather than just complaining they show that the problems were real enough to actually pick up stakes and leave. The exiters shock people out of complacency with an unfakable high cost signal — because it’s a huge pain to leave. The ultimate civic duty, patriotism *as* dissent.

5) In general, we need both Satoshis and Satyas. People who execute the exit *and* people who tough it out for the turnaround.

6) But these are complementary strategies: because both Satoshi and Satya understand there is something deeply broken with the prevailing order. Neither are Ballmers.

2023-08-09|The upside of being a joiner.fullText:
The upside of being a joiner is that you’re part of an institution. There’s an established business model, name recognition, a baseline level of social legitimacy.

However, these days that institutional safety really isn’t all its cracked up to be. 

People who joined big companies at high salaries in the 2010s and didn’t take conscious risks gradually got acclimatized to high spending and low work output.

If they get suddenly laid off in their late 30s or 40s, it can be difficult to get a new job at the same or higher compensation level.

One option is to constantly take risks and reinvent yourself every ~5 years. You keep opting out and leveling up. That’s doable for a certain kind of personality, but it is quite hard to do. 

The alternative is to watch every dime like the leanFIRE people, and refrain from unnecessary consumption, in the assumption that today’s “safe” salary may not be sustainable. You might couple this with moving to an extremely low cost locale.

But that also means opting out in a different way. You’d have a typical job perhaps, but an atypical spending pattern.

Anyway, Disney has a market cap of $160B. It’s been around for generations. It owns iconic brands. And it’s probably still a decent job. 

But I have a feeling that the extreme corporate risk aversion manifested here — to the point that they either voluntarily divested a half billion dollar asset, or were forced to by hostile regulators — isn’t going to serve them well in a time when all the cartoons can be generated by artificial intelligence  and all the engagement is going to iconoclastic individuals.

Like Portnoy.

2023-08-08|Some follow up thoughts. 1).fullText:
Some follow up thoughts.

1) In addition to using AI to inexpensively *read* corporate PDFs, of course you also want to use it to cheaply *write* corporate PDFs.

Because if we go back to the analogy of a folder of corporate contracts as a database, right now every interaction with that database has a *cost*. It’s not just reading contracts that has expense. To write a contract also means paying fees[a] to lawyers and governments.

So we want to start thinking of these as paired read/write operations, where we use the same AI tools to write contracts as we do to query them. You’d thus get a consistent set of prompts, templates, and file naming conventions across your business.

It’s create-read-update-delete (CRUD), but for the PDF contracts that currently constitute corporations.

2) The other extension is to do AI summarization not just for PDFs but for emails and wikis. Again, this all may be obvious, but I’ll write it up anyway in the off chance it wasn’t.

As you know, we’ve now seen the advent of AI synthesis of new content in tools like Superhuman (@rahulvohra) and Notion (@akothari). And this is already useful, and I pay for it.

However, AI querying and summarization of natural language emails and wikis is, in my view, much more valuable.

For example, can you query an entire mailbox with 100k+ emails to output a clean table with all relevant emails and attachments for a given deal?

Can you summarize hundreds of pages of daily notes from a tool like Notion or Roam (@Conaw) and tell the user something they didn’t know, like things they noted as important two years ago but had forgotten about?

If so, that would really start turning emails and wikis into second brains. A human can’t read 1000s of pages per day, but an AI now can.

[a]: The onchain analog to legal fees is transaction fees. To update a smart contract is to pay fees to engineers and blockchains.

2023-08-08|COPILOT FOR CORPORATIONS How.fullText:
COPILOT FOR CORPORATIONS

How do you double the value of cloud storage? Add AI summarization of PDFs, thereby allowing businesses to replace millions in legal bills with thousands in SaaS fees. It’d be like Github Copilot, but for corporations.

As context, every founder and investor has at least one huge directory of PDFs. Your corporate bylaws, your employment agreements, your investment docs — this folder is essentially a database of contracts.

But right now, this crucial database can only be read one file at a time, and often only by a legal expert. Yeah, you can do keyword search, but that’s not quite the same thing as comprehending a 200 page PDF summarizing an acquisition.

So what people do today is: pay expensive lawyers to ask questions about the docs. This is the most expensive search engine in the world, often costing hundreds of dollars per query, and taking hours if not days between each query.

But now there’s an alternative. OpenAI has added several AI PDF readers as plugins to GPT4. And while they’re early and finicky and often can’t read many PDFs due to OCR and other issues, they are amazing when they work.

The next step is to just bring that tech in situ. We need to make it run in the background of every cloud storage app, so you don’t need to manually upload countless PDFs to a new service.

That means configurable AI summarization of every PDF, every folder of PDFs, every folder of folders. 

You might set up some prompts to run on every PDF (“what’s this document about in one sentence”), and others from collections of related PDFs (“read all these employment agreements and generate a table of salaries”). You could even have AI suggest automatic, consistent titles for all files.

These prompts would execute asynchronously upon file upload, like video encoding. So you wouldn’t put a ton of load on the server, and it would process your files when it had a chance. 

Moreover, you’d have to set up the privacy settings just right, but once you did…the AI that read *all* of your PDFs would be like your corporate lawyer. They’d know everything about your entity and its history and be available day or night to answer questions — in seconds for a few cents, rather than days for many dollars.

Of course, this doesn’t put good lawyers out of work. It just allows them to focus on higher order questions. And they could still be cc’d (at much lower cost) to provide attorney/client privilege on every AI question you ask.

Still, as PDF sharing is perhaps the number one enterprise use case for cloud storage, reducing legal expenses could be a huge growth opportunity for Zoho (@svembu), Box (@levie), and Dropbox (@drewhouston).

If they shift just a few billable hours of legal work per year per person into SaaS fees for cloud, that could easily be +$1000/year.

These companies even have their own internal corporate document collections to use as training data, to dogfood the product and generate the top 5 most useful prompts for different kinds of document collections.

Anyway, all of this is probably obvious to them and I wouldn’t be surprised if they are already working on it. But if not — first thing we do, let’s automate all the lawyers.

They inherited the cultural tactic from the UK, whose goal for generations was to maintain the “balance of power” on the European continent by playing one against another. Then the US applied it on a global scale.

The Soviets were also pretty good at this. They had plenty of spies through the US as Venona revealed. And even got the US to fight Japan for them, as McMeekin wrote about.[2]

In many ways the Cold War was a contest of who could out-manipulate whom. Hot Wars, by contrast, are more about who can out-manufacture whom. The greatest countries are great at both.

The 20th century US, like the UK before it, was unusual in that it combined the financial cleverness of a tiny Switzerland with the industrial might of a giant like Germany. So it was good at both media/money/manipulation and manufacturing.

It had Wall Street *and* West Point, Hollywood *and* Detroit. The virtual and the physical. All the flash and all of the substance. For decades, at least.

The Soviets also had quite a bit of subversive guile and industrial might — but ultimately less than the US. You could do a whole thread like this though on how Stalin pitted one ethnic group against the other in the USSR.

2023-07-10|CENTRAL BANKS ARE BUYING GOLD.fullText:
CENTRAL BANKS ARE BUYING GOLD

Invesco just released its annual global survey of 85 sovereign wealth funds and 57 central banks, collectively managing $21T.

And what does it say?

1) Flight to gold. "Amid volatile [bond] yields, 2022 saw a flight to gold, questions around the US dollar’s future as the world’s reserve currency, and increased diversification of currency holdings."

2) Gold hedges inflation. "Reserve portfolio managers identified inflation as a key risk...69% of central banks countering global inflation through gold allocations."

3) Gold as a safe-haven. "96% of central banks increasing gold allocations cited its status as a ‘safe-haven’ asset"

4) Sanctions are a major factor. "A substantial percentage of central banks are concerned about the precedent set by the US freezing of Russian reserves, with the majority (58%) agreeing that the event has made gold more attractive."

5) Physical gold in vaults only. "Consequently, central banks now prefer to hold physical gold rather than gold ETFs or derivatives..."

6) Not even London is trusted. "We...had it held in London...but we’ve now transferred our gold reserves back to our own country to keep it safe – its role now is to be a safe-haven asset” said one central bank based in the West.

7) Yuan rising as a trade currency, not a 'reserve' currency. "A considerable proportion do expect a shift towards renminbi (27% of central banks), but expectations differ based on the region."

8) India now the #1 emerging market to invest in, over China. "India has now overtaken China as the most attractive Emerging Market for investing in Emerging Market debt."

9) Dollar is being hedged with EM currencies (!). "While the US dollar is expected to retain its dominance, central banks are increasingly exploring diversification into Emerging Market currencies to hedge against volatility."

10) Everyone wants to de-dollarize. "People have been looking for alternatives to the dollar and euro for a long time and they would’ve gone to them already if there were any suitable alternatives."

--

In summary, they're buying gold, holding it in vaults, and preparing for high levels of inflation. They're reallocating capital away from volatile bonds, investing in India, and expecting the yuan to be used for trade rather than stored in reserves.

And they're all seeking alternatives to the dollar, but haven't found it yet. However...I think their actions show that the alternative to the dollar is already here, even if not recognized as such.

De-dollarization is decentralization.

The reserve role is being taken up by hard assets like gold (and Bitcoin, as even Blackrock now admits). The trade role is taken up by currencies like the yuan (and rupee, and others). And other roles like payments, smart contracts, and the like are being taken up by different states or networks.

So the dollar is getting unbundled. When there's an alternative in every situation, much of the dollar's coercive power goes away. And that's the theme of this report — sovereigns are seeking an exit from the dollar, and a hedge against its uncertain future.

https://t.co/hnJYxogxQ3

2023-07-09|Some notes. 1) An argument l.fullText:
Some notes.

1) An argument like this is refreshing relative to the mumbo-jumbo we hear from today’s Fed.

Chase is *agreeing* that the money is all an illusion, and all that matters is whether governments can whip (or incentivize?) their citizens into a productive lather. This was more possible at the time due to technology favoring total centralization of power, and less possible today.

2) Chase’s viewpoint is *adjacent* to the broken windows fallacy, but that’s not the entirety of it.

In Bastiat’s classical broken windows setup, someone smashes a shopkeeper’s window. And we see the money the shopkeeper allocates to the glazier for repairs but not what he would have spent it on — and we thus mistake the spending for economic activity *caused* by destruction.

But Chase’s initial conditions are different. He’s saying a country is essentially out of money, but then suddenly discovers productive capacity in the context of a war. For it to match the broken window setup, the shopkeeper wouldn’t have a shop. So then, where’s the money coming from?

3) In each case you can argue with his examples. For example, Russia under the New Economic Policy in the late 20s wasn’t as bad as Lenin’s war communism, so they would have had more wealth to work with. 

And the American economy was hamstrung by the New Deal and (relatively) set free by war production, where many regulatory barriers were relaxed. For example, antitrust and labor laws (like Walsh-Healey) were suspended or ignored.

4) But there is something to what is being said here. There is a capacity for rebirth in a country (like the German Economic Miracle after the war) that isn’t typically there in a shorter-lived company. There’s also truth in the idea that the right management and motivation can get much more productivity out of a population.

5) However, I think it’s wrong to say that incentives (and therefore money) don’t matter because of the experience of wartime economies.

To the contrary, perhaps the most important reason war changes the economy has to do with the introduction of a huge new incentive for everyone: basically, work fast or die.

2023-07-09|Yesterday\u2019s Keynesians w.fullText:
Yesterday’s Keynesians were more interesting than today’s Keynesians. They founded the system, after all.

—
WHERE’S THE MONEY COMING FROM?
By Stuart Chase, 1943

IN 1925, Russia had been through a devastating war and a violent internal revolution. Her currency had been destroyed in a runaway price inflation, she was the world’s worst financial risk abroad and she had very little gold. Yet by the end of the first Five Year Plan in 1933, Russia had invested some 60 billion rubles in factories, new cities, cities, hydroelectric developments, armaments, houses, schools. There stood the new plant, ugly and solid. Without it Russia could never have met the onslaught of Hitler’s armies.

Where did the money come from?

In 1933 it was freely prophesied that Italy could not invade Ethiopia. She had no credit abroad and almost no gold. The effort would bankrupt her. Italy went ahead, conquered Ethiopia, and emerged without financial collapse.

Where did the money come from?

Hitler took over a Germany which was technically bankrupt. It had defaulted on its foreign obligations. When he proposed to build a powerful army, together with all kinds of grandiose public works, he was laughed at in London and New York. Germany was insolvent, and the whole idea was preposterous. The nations of Europe which have trembled under the thunder of panzer divisions know that Hitler built even more terribly than he promised.

Where did the money come from?

When Japan began to rattle her sword in the direction of Indo-China and challenge the United States and the British Empire, wiseacres said it was a bluff. The long years of the war in China had reduced the Japanese economy to a bag of bones. She was bankrupt and could not sustain a real fight. Yet she opened a new attack with devastating fury, and with military equipment in planes, tanks, artillery, ships, that was as excellent as it was unexpected.

Where did the money come from?

In 1939, the United States Congress declined to appropriate $4 billions for highways, conservation, hospitals, freight cars, in the bitterly contested “lend-spend” bill. It was widely held that the bill would lead to ruin and national bankruptcy. Yet since the fall of France in 1940, Congress has appropriated almost $300 billions for armaments–seventy-five times as much as the lend-spend bill–and a large fraction of it has already gone into tanks and guns. Far from being ruined, our national vitality has never been more vigorous, and great financial moguls assure us that we shall be able to swing the national debt.

Where did the money come from?

After the war America will need to maintain full employment, operate its industries at substantial capacity, provide the essentials of life for all its own citizens, and help foreign peoples who are starving and unable to pay for the supplies. There will be a towering political demand for a world delivered from chronic depression.

Where will the money come from?

…it is clear from these examples that what a great nation can “afford” in periods of crisis depends not on its money but on its man power and its goods. Russia, Italy, Germany, Japan, the United States, all used money in the situations mentioned, but money was obviously not the dominant factor. Man power and materials were the dominant factor.

Yet at other times, when crisis was not so acute, the money for necessary tasks could not be found. Unemployment, insecurity, want, dragged on. This is a puzzling paradox. At certain times a nation can afford what at other times, with no less money, it cannot afford. At certain times we are afraid of national bankruptcy, and at other times we give it hardly a thought.

https://t.co/4UDLi8p6qD

2023-07-09|THE NETWORK WAR I really lik.fullText:
THE NETWORK WAR

I really like @eugenewei’s writing, and recommend you read his piece. But I’d argue it misses the core point of the last few years.

Namely, that this isn’t primarily a product conversation anymore. We’re in the middle of the Network War, where all previously neutral institutions — online and offline — are captured by one tribe to be wielded against other tribes.

Yes, that’s Twitter and Facebook and Google — but it’s also the media, the courts, the dollar, the banking system, and the international rules-based order itself.

Every one of these institutions and more besides is caught in the middle of a massive multiplayer battle. There are at least 2-3 main combatants within the US (blues, reds, and tech) and many more internationally (like China, Russia, and India). More if you count Bitcoin and crypto as independent tribes.

Just like physical territory can switch hands multiple times during the course of an offline war, digital territory can switch hands in an online war. And both can get damaged in the process — causing some of the issues Eugene describes.

But unlike a physical war, this network war is a battle for minds, not lands. Winning digital territory means the CEO is tweeting your memes and the brand is flying your colors. The digital battlefield is of real-world importance, because if you flip enough people online — enough users, enough capital — you change the world offline. The keyboard is often mightier than the sword.

Anyway — the point is that Twitter started to become a battleground in 2013. It’s more optimized for being a battleground than perhaps any other forum. That is its emergent purpose: to facilitate player-vs-player online, the endless war of all against all.

And the capture of that battleground itself by Elon was a meta-move that was theoretically permissible by the rules of the game, but something perhaps only the richest man in the world could pull off.

Everything else Eugene is (justifiably!) complaining about is a side effect of being caught in the middle of that digital battlefield, in the middle of the Network War.

I’m not saying the current owner made all the right moves, but he did successfully push back on a nightmarish 1984-like style of speech and thought controls that was being imposed on a previously free society, as documented here[1].

Those who abetted this inside and outside Twitter have now been exposed by the Twitter Files, stripped of their blue checks, repudiated by the courts[2], and deprived of their online influence — though it was already in freefall beforehand[3]. This is much more important than the details of the chronological feed, in my view at least.

That said: I’m completely sympathetic to people who’ve found themselves caught in the middle of this, though this war has been raging for at least 10 years now. And if you want to hang out with your friends in a moderated space, or build decentralized alternatives, that’s completely reasonable and a good course of action.

But Twitter itself shouldn’t really be analyzed as a product. It’s a digital warzone. And that war is only going to heat up as we move into 2024.

[2]: https://t.co/i9OQDIEfos
[3]: https://t.co/mCPSi9xyND

2023-07-07|Here, I\u2019m using narrativ.fullText:
Here, I’m using narrative in the broader sense of the overarching story that defines the self-understanding of a group.

Just like many people are mono-lingual, many people are mono-narrative. And they can’t learn new ones after a certain age.

Moreover, just like some languages are easier to pick up if you know English, while others are more distant, some narratives are closer in ideology space and others are further.

This is an explanation for why people can understand one political narrative, but not another. Or why the gold narrative is adjacent to the Bitcoin narrative, and why both can be hard to understand for people raised fiat-monolingual.

A narrative requires space in your brain roughly comparable to a dialect.

It is partly literally linguistic — there are phrases that are characteristic of some ideological positions, like “fiat”. But it’s also cultural, historical, moral, and social.

The way in which it’s related to language is that you need to really immerse yourself in a narrative’s premises to be able to speak fluently to someone else with that narrative.

If you foot fault on a phrase — for example saying “CCP” rather than “CPC” is a tell in China — then you’re speaking the narrative with a strong accent. Maybe so strong that the other side won’t listen anymore.

PS: You could start quantifying this by using LLMs to rewrite text in different styles.

As we get better at explaining models, perhaps we can see what parts of the model are activated for different narratives, and what the underlying training corpora was for those different parts.

If the model needs be to trained on books 1-100 to speak in this way, but 101-200 to speak in another way, that’s good evidence that acquisition of another narrative is nontrivial.

2023-07-06|IS THREADS A THREAT? Faceboo.fullText:
IS THREADS A THREAT?

Facebook’s clones of Snapchat and TikTok have been fairly successful, but haven’t killed either Snapchat or TikTok. I think that’s the base case.

An alternative scenario is Google Plus, which came out strong but didn’t have staying power. But Facebook has far more social DNA than Google ever did.

It may boil down to whether Instagram users really want to post to a *new* social network.

That is, why not just implement Threads as a new tab within Instagram? Like Instagram added TikTok-like short videos.

I’m sure that was discussed internally as an alternative to doing Threads. One reason is that launching Threads as a new app certainly gets more attention, and maybe pulls in some disaffected Twitter users who want a different moderation policy.

The thing is — Instagram is for people who go outside. It’s just a totally different culture of good-looking, well-adjusted, visually-oriented people. Very different culturally from Twitter’s endless political warfare.

It will be interesting to see what happens when the kind of person who left Musk for Mastodon tries out Threads…and is suddenly digitally surrounded by fitness influencers and models.

Come for the moderation, stay for the muscles?

This is part of the optical illusion at the heart of the system.

On the one hand, the Fed Chair is more powerful than the President and we hang on every word.

On the other hand, the Fed isn’t responsible for anything and if you die following their guidance it’s your fault for believing them.

2023-07-03|At a minimum, hundreds of ins.fullText:
At a minimum, hundreds of institutions[1] have problems — which should tell you that it wasn’t trivial to “manage duration risk” of this magnitude.

In more detail:

1) You can hedge a move to say 1.1% from 1%, but not 1% to 5% in a year

2) Hedging is also expensive, complex, and gives up scarce margin

3) Hedging didn’t seem necessary in 2021 because you’d had 10 years of low/zero rates and a strong commitment from the Fed to keep them low indefinitely[2]

4) More than that: the Fed said inflation was a conspiracy theory in 2021, so it was low status to hedge!

5) Put all that together. Most banks are run by risk averse NPC committees these days. You think that in mid 2021 they were going to spend a big chunk of their margin hedging a risk that hadn’t happened for 10 years that the Fed told them repeatedly wouldn’t happen?

6) Moreover, hedging just moves risk from one guy to another. Someone is stuck holding these horrible bonds. It doesn’t fix the devaluation

7) And in many cases the rulebook won’t let you hedge, eg if you have moved them into hold to maturity you can’t sell them

8) Finally, duration risk isn’t really duration risk in this case, it’s devaluation  policy. Look at Powell’s comments in 2012 — he knew rate hikes would cause massive losses after big bond sales.

Etc etc. TLDR: all the hedging duration risk stuff is 20/20 hindsight. It’s like asking five years from now “why didn’t you hedge debasement risk”, as if debasement was a establishment-approved thing to hedge.

2023-07-03|HOW THE FED F\u2019ED INSURAN.fullText:
HOW THE FED F’ED INSURANCE

It’s quite likely that many insurance companies are underwater. But if so, that’s the fault of the Fed, not Florida.

Why? Well, one of the insurance companies named below is American Coastal. And Weiss Ratings reports[0] they put 77% of their portfolio into safe, investment-grade bonds. Problem is, thanks to the Fed, bonds are no longer safe.

See, many institutions bought supposedly safe bonds from the government in 2021.[1] But then that same government did a massive surprise devaluation[2] of all of the bonds it had just sold — screwing over its biggest customers, from banks to insurance companies, causing the largest losses in bond history[3], and saddling institutions what Stanford researchers estimate to be literally trillions[4] in unrealized losses.

These bond losses remain “unrealized” so long as people don’t come looking for their money. But when they do — like during a bank run when banks must pay out, or during hurricane season when insurance companies must fork over cash — then bad assets are sold and losses become “realized.”

And then we all “realize” that the poor dumb institutions that bought US government bonds in 2021 are actually insolvent — unless the Fed prints to paper over a bond crisis the Fed itself caused. Which it will do, over and over again, until the crisis devalues the dollar itself.

Anyway, this is what happened in March 2022 when five huge banks died[5] in quick succession, followed by a quick print[6] to cover up the Fed’s failure. This is why Roubini[7] is saying “most” banks are insolvent, why Germany’s central bank apparently has negative equity[8], and why Bank of America has $100B in unrealized losses[9].

This is all just the tip of the iceberg. 

Jerome Powell and Janet Yellen are bond villains. They destroyed every institution that trusted their words in 2021. They said inflation was transitory and that they’d keep rates low[10]. They sold billions in bonds on that false pretense. Then the Fed executed a surprise rate hike, devaluing all the bonds the government had just sold, and turning Treasuries into the new toxic waste.

I wrote all this up here[2] and here[11], even mentioning insurance companies as bust months ago. The thing to understand is that this financial hurricane won’t be limited to Florida.

2023-06-28|Well, people aren't all going.fullText:
Well, people aren't all going to be seropositive to every new strain that comes out.

And Moderna/Pfizer are still developing new vaccines, in part for these new strains.

So you'd get statistical power because you'd be doing challenge trials with new strains that most people haven't built antibodies to.

Moreover, the new strains may be less virulent, if they're like Omicron, though that's not guaranteed. If so that reduces the risk of live virus exposure (but perhaps also the perceived need for new vaccines).

Also, even if this experiment is in theory redundant with existing data (a) it's cheap relative to the cost of having mass distrust in public health and (b) we should be funding way more replication studies anyway given the broader replication crisis.

2023-06-26|TECH VS MEDIA What actually.fullText:
TECH VS MEDIA

What actually happened is that tech got negative coverage after it negatively affected those producing the coverage.

Here’s the sequence of events.

1) 2000-2008: tech and media ignored each other. Tech thought content was a dead end after Terry Semel[1], so they focused on the hard task of building pipes and just let users supply content[2]. Media though tech was a dead end after dotcom crash, so they focused on blowing up Iraq.

2) 2008-2012: tech soared and took ~$50B in media revenue after the financial crisis

3) 2013: media needed tech to re-elect Obama[3], but then after the 2012 election they brought the knives out

4) 2013-2020: seven years of techlash from the media, to demonize the sector that was disrupting them and colonize it with establishment-sympathetic figures

5) 2021: pyrrhic victory, with the establishment capturing Google and big tech at the expense of spending down their trust[4], alienating founders and investors of the next generation, and losing their best writers like @ggreenwald and @mtaibbi

6) 2022: return of the founder, with Elon, Jack, Zuck and others asserting themselves in different ways. Tech also built and scaled its own media outlets over this time period, particular on podcasts and Twitter where legacy wasn’t as strong

7) 2023+: the combination of generative AI, decentralized social media, a billion Indians coming online, and more means legacy media is finished, so battleground is moving to the legacy financial system

TLDR: tech wrecked the business model of legacy media, and thus started receiving negative coverage.

2023-06-25|CHEATING DEATH IS GOOD Peopl.fullText:
CHEATING DEATH IS GOOD

People often associate performance enhancing drugs with “cheating”. And of course it’s true that if you’re an athlete it’s cheating and against the rules. But there’s nothing wrong with cheating death.

Put another way: Lance Armstrong shouldn’t have won the Tour De France, but his chemists could have won the Nobel Prize for medicine.

How did they bring a man back from testicular cancer[1] to “winning” seven championships against likely drug-aided competitors?

Take the athletic competition out of the picture for a second. Many cancer patients would like to know what exactly Lance Armstrong’s regimen was.

Yes, it’s some mix of EPO, Andriol, cortisone, HGH, and actovegin.[2] (Note in particular the apparent efficacy of blood transfusions, another signal for the @bryan_johnson / parabiosis school of thought!)

But I haven’t seen the full clinical writeup, let alone a proposed scaling of this (or similar) interventions to other cancer patients that want to get back to top condition.

Partly this is because the conventional wisdom is that performance enhancing drugs are always life shortening, that there are side effects and trade offs, that there is no free lunch, that Lance will now die sooner, etc.

But we should be skeptical of this kind of Icarus instinct. Trying to fly doesn’t necessarily mean your wings will fall off. We fly every day.

Similarly, it’s not obvious that we’re anywhere close to Pareto optimal health. There is likely enormous room for improvement given modern technology. We just sequenced the genome 20 years ago. We’re at the beginning of the human self-improvement arc.

So: what if the kind of treatments that these athletes get might be more broadly useful to society? What if you could monitor and engineer away the side effects?

We’ve managed to do that for many other drugs, like folk remedies where we figured out the active ingredient.

It’s worth thinking about.

[1]: https://t.co/ddbvDIQz6q
[2]: https://t.co/ih87KzQwXm

And your fault for not hedging...

2023-06-19|SCIENCE > CENSORSHIP @fcholl.fullText:
SCIENCE > CENSORSHIP

@fchollet is a wonderful engineer that's written a great AI book. But in his post, he compares discussing vaccines to supporting fascism.

I can't agree. 

1) First, many of the vaccine-hesitant early on were actually African Americans that saw the shadow of Tuskegee in the COVID shots, as several outlets reported[1,2].

2) Second, it's kind of weird to say that Nazism is both (a) mindlessly supporting a totalitarian state *and* (b) disobediently asking questions of your government.

3) Third, and most obviously, many on the other side were *also* calling people Nazis for mandating injections while censoring speech. You aren't going to convince them by calling them Nazis back.

4) Fourth, almost 50% of civil servants were hesitant to take the vaccine at one point, which shows how deep the resistance was![3]

So: rather than the infinite loop of everyone calling each other Hitler till the end of time, why not a rational discussion?

HOW YOU MIGHT DO THAT
Thing is, I’m as pro-biotech as it gets. I was sticking my neck out to talk about COVID back when establishment journalists were calling everyone paranoid racists for mentioning it, because I do believe in the public good.[4] And the thing is: there is genuine scientific achievement here in terms of mRNA vaccines!

So: why seize defeat from the jaws of victory by yelling at people and pounding them with all manner of threats? I think I know why, unfortunately. It's because everything is tribal warfare now and every issue is politicized. Even if it should be positive-sum, it's made zero-sum or even negative-sum.

Still, here's a sketch of how you might make the case.

1) First, go through all the observational studies, where you show relative morbidity and mortality for vaccinated and non-vaccinated, with every covariate, and the raw data publicly available for re-analysis.

2) Then, if people still disagree, maybe you can conduct a challenge trial[5], where group A opts in to being exposed to live virus and group B to getting the vaccine. Yeah, I know, there is risk. 

But (a) this is actually what science is (namely  controlled experiments) and (b) this is already being done de facto at the level of society as a whole, with millions of people exposing themselves to live virus. So we might as well get it over with in a small group that’s opted in. Think of them as military heros if you want, as they'd be taking a conscious risk to help save other people's lives.

3) Finally, who knows — maybe you can even do something with organoids where you don’t need to expose an individual to either live virus *or* vaccine right away, but can instead take a tissue sample and establish a patient-specific organoid and test on that, as a proxy for the patient themselves. Looks like there's some promising initial work on that[6], though it probably wouldn't substitute for the challenge trial.

All this starts putting us in the realm of scientific discussion, as befits a serious matter of public health. Or, you know, everyone can just call each other Hitler forever.

The reason to focus here is that it’s the key branch in worldview.

Many people think that DC has infinite money or an invincible military or both. Even ~55% of my followers believe this. 

Those two premises are really one premise, as fiat currency is backed by men with guns. Given infinite money, you can buy infinite guns. And given infinite guns, you can force anyone to accept even devalued money.

So if you believe one or both of those premises, you shouldn’t even be mad online at those who don’t. Your advantage is after all so overwhelming that nothing can dent it. The world order will be stable forever. Just use the printer or the bomber or both.

In other words: chill brah, we got this! The demographics means the biggest rival will fall into a ditch. The economics means no one can replace the dollar. The politics doesn’t mean anything, and that’s just the mess of our beautiful system anyway.

Basically: it’s a unipolar world, still a huge lead, will be forever, and you can keep screwing up indefinitely without consequence — including another multi-trillion dollar print on the scale of 2008 or beyond — due to the enormous advantage afforded by technology, geography, etc.

However if you take the other view — if you think that fiat currency is backed by men with guns, and that both the currency and the guns are looking quite iffy these days — then you need to start thinking about how to defend freedom if history follows an unexpected branch.

2023-06-13|Yeah, but I think it's worth.fullText:
Yeah, but I think it's worth thinking through.

1) 140M Russians (including many who were against the war) were summarily deplatformed from a variety of tech services in March 2022. For Google, with 4B+ users, that was just a few % of their users. They could blackhole an entire country without much consequence. So they might be able to do it to 500M crypto holders.

2) Or think about social media before 2016. Twitter used to call itself the "free speech wing of the free speech party". Then from 2016 till 2022, the speech controls came fast and furious, once states felt that social media actually threatened them.

In 2021 in particular, the CEOs of major tech companies were encouraged to deplatform a sitting president and his supporters in order to keep the republic going. And they did so.

3) In my view, we are at the beginning of a complicated dance between the state and the network on cryptocurrency. Some states will be rabidly against, some will be vocally for, some states will be for only *some* networks, and so on.

If you analyze the battlefield, though, the most important underappreciated technical threat out there in my view isn't the NSA or CCP — but Apple, Google, and Microsoft.

If the CEOs of those three companies are ordered by DC to seize private keys in order to keep the US financial system running...if cryptocurrency becomes as financially important as social media is politically important...what'll happen?

4) I'm not saying the answer is purely technological. It may include political components, that deter Apple from trying such a thing in (say) Texas or El Salvador or UAE for fear of having other penalties applied to it.

It might include moral components, or societal components, though those might only be as binding as Twitter's "commitment" to free speech.

I do think we should think about it.

2023-06-12|This is a deep question. My s.fullText:
This is a deep question. My short response is that I’d have agreed with you 75 years ago but not today.

Just as preface, I take zero pleasure in any of these observations. I’m a win/win person and the ideal would have been for the West to continue improving even as India also got its act together. But that’s not what I see.

With that said, the longer response:

1) India at the time of independence was a collection of princely states with no prior history of union before the British Raj. And it wasn’t trivial for Sardar Patel and others to unify it and forge a cohesive national identity. But today to my great surprise India is in the middle of its centralization arc, and is perhaps the most unified it’s ever been.

2) The US in the 1950s was similar to India in the 2020s — a polyglot mixture of ethnic groups from across a continent that was nevertheless unified by nationalism and cultural similarities.

The most obvious signal of practical unity is that today’s India and the DC of the 1950s could cost-effectively build public works (the Golden Quadrilateral, the Interstate Highway System), but the India of the past and the DC of the present could not (the License Raj, the California High Speed Rail).

3) The US of the present resembles the India of the past, in a reversal that I would have thought improbably bizarre even 10-15 years ago.

India had an absolutely world class group of smart people trapped in a tragic commons and ruled by a dysfunctional state. It was the country  wracked by communal riots, socialist lunatics, and racialist obsessions. And it gave birth to an impressive diaspora, exiting economic craziness and ethnic conflict. Now that sounds like California.

4) Finally, regarding the US of the distant past, it actually *was* essentially 13 separate countries at the time of independence. See video below starting at 0:48.

“It's important to remember that the United States of America was not originally a single country. It was a collection of 13 separate countries. The 13 colonies that were participating in the rebellion had each been separate from each other, distinct colonies with ties between themselves and Britain, but not really ties amongst themselves, between the different colonies.

So when the 13 colonies declared their independence, they did so not as a single unified country but as 13 separate countries in association with each other — what we would today call an international organization — in
order to accomplish their common goal.”
https://t.co/Ya9vhloL3G

2023-06-12|The Soviet Union was a nuclea.fullText:
The Soviet Union was a nuclear-armed superpower with roughly 300M citizens. It fell in two years. And after it fell, identities that had once seemed so important fell by the wayside. You couldn’t really be pro-Soviet or anti-Soviet anymore, because the Soviet Union did not exist.

So what did people do?

- Some built up the newly independent Estonia into a tech powerhouse[1]
- Some emigrated to the US or Israel[2]
- Some rebuilt the Russian Orthodox Church[3]
- Some tried to restore the Soviet Empire[4]
- Some turned to organized crime[5]
- Some focused on extracting natural resources[6]
- Some fought in the dozens of post-Soviet ethnic conflicts, like the Tajikistani Civil War[7]
- Some eventually aligned with China, especially the Central Asians[8]
- Some eventually aligned with the West, especially the Central Europeans[9]
- Some pined for the communist past, despite its problems[10]
- Some embraced the capitalist present, despite *its* problems[11]
- Many were just confused[12]

In other words, people scattered to the winds. It was a mix of exit, voice, and loyalty.

2023-06-10|So, it\u2019s a tough problem.fullText:
So, it’s a tough problem, but here’s what a realistic solution might look like:

1) First, stop thinking you can win a conventional war against a physically stronger opponent.

2) Second, stop thinking you can level up in the physical world overnight by printing money and willing it into being. Industrial policy is like venture capital, it’s easy to spend money but very hard to do profitably.

3) Third, stop pushing countries to decouple because they will be forced to choose China over the US — or else they don’t get countless basic physical goods.

4) Fourth, start thinking about what a realistic solution looks like given those constraints. 

Reshoring manufacturing would probably mean AI-based factories with heavy use of robots, along with radical changes to building codes, labor law, and environmental regulations. So, that right there is arguably politically impossible in the current climate.

You’d want to combine that with a modest foreign policy that avoids provoking a war that you can’t win, until you’ve spent literally decades rebuilding your strength.

So, this is also probably impossible because many people don’t want to hear that their military isn’t infinitely physically powerful, and indeed is arguably the underdog.

But hey, at least a note of realism was sounded.

2023-05-19|DON'T GO FROM WOKISM TO JINGO.fullText:
DON'T GO FROM WOKISM TO JINGOISM

Many people are critical of wokism.
And they should be.
Wokism simply denies many domestic realities.
But a militaristic, nationalistic jingoism is also bad.
Because it denies many foreign realities.
If wokism is Democrat PC...
Then jingoism is Republican PC.

What are the foreign realities that jingoism denies?

1) That the US failed in the forever wars, killed a lot of people unnecessarily, burnt insane amounts of money, and should at least reflect on this.

2) That US foreign policy was on balance better than the USSR from 1945-1991, but gradually turned destructive after that, and since 2003 has arguably done more harm than good — particularly in the Middle East — to the US as well as the world.

3) That as a consequence, many countries no longer consider the US to be the guarantor of order that it was during the Cold War, but an agent of anarchy. For example, this is why legislators in Germany have accused the US of doing the Nord Stream bombing and want it to pull out troops.[1]

4) That the US is not the manufacturing powerhouse it used to be, that it couldn't financially nuke Russia into submission[2], and that it's finding it hard to produce enough ammo to beat Russia[3], let alone China. 

5) That now Kupchan in CFR[4] and Blinken[5] have essentially said they're going to sue for peace with Russia over Ukraine, involving China as a partner.

6) That China is actually extremely strong in manufacturing capability, with 10-100X advantages over the US in many key areas like steel and shipbuilding[6]. 

7) That the US is unfortunately no longer the manufacturing superpower[7] it was in WW2, and may not be able to win[8] a prolonged conventional war with China at the present time, so should think twice about it. It's like fighting your factory — it's not even about high-tech, China can screw you by withholding screws.

8) Finally, just as it was completely possible to be both (a) against Al Qaeda and (b) against the Iraq War and (c) for surgical counterterrorism instead, it's possible to be both (a) against the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the Chinese surveillance state while (b) also supporting moves towards peace with Russia [like even Kupchan[4] and Blinken[5] now do] and avoiding confrontation with China.

9) The goal instead should be to build economic and manufacturing capability peacefully to once again become an admirable country and thereby restore soft power.

10) Fundamentally, it is the erosion of US soft power — quality manufacturing, respected media, a stable financial system —  that has led to the overreliance on hard power.

Basically, China used to respect the US but doesn't anymore[9] after 2020, because they feel they are domestically out-executing the US.

The way to turn that around is not by shooting guns, but by building buildings. Build a clean, futuristic, admirable[10] society that is once again the wonder of the world. Then everyone will want to emulate the US.

That's neither wokism nor jingoism. Neither riots nor bombings. It's not denying domestic or foreign realities. You need to embrace the constraints of reality to build an admirable society.

2023-05-19|STOPPING THE BACKDOOR ATTACK.fullText:
STOPPING THE BACKDOOR ATTACK

In 2010, even after Twitter and Facebook helped catalyze the Arab Spring, people still would have thought it implausible if you'd said "in ten years, the most important political issue in the world for a few days will be whether the President of the United States could tweet."

But it was.

Similarly, in 2023, even after El Salvador has adopted Bitcoin, people still think it's implausible to say "by the end of this decade, the most important political issue in the world may be whether bankrupt governments have sufficient Bitcoin to fund their operations."

But it could be.

And in such a circumstance, what will desperate governments do? As of 2023, I don't think the conventional 51% attack by mining is something the US government could easily pull off. Maybe China could, but most mining is now outside China.

Instead, the federal government may try to compel Apple and Google (and other tech companies) to hunt for private keys on the servers, devices, and browsers they control. And to remit any stolen funds to a cash-hungry federal government.

This isn't cyberterrorism, it's cyberwar. It's not some random hacker who manages to sneak out a file. It's when the CEO of a company gives the lawful order to to hack their customers. This is similar to what happened to 140M Russians designated enemies of the state in early 2022 — every tech company turned on their former customers.

What's the possible target? We're talking billions of iPhones and Android phones, Mac laptops and Chrome browsers, Google Docs and Gmail. China could do the same with the Chinese smartphone manufacturers.

What's the possible defense? This is a tough situation. It's quite possible Tim Cook stands up to the pressure. He's been good on end-to-end encryption and stood up to the establishment on the CSAM on-device scanning initiative[1], which was an obvious way to get the snout under the tent.

If you can't trust the operating system itself, things get tricky. Linux is an answer but Linux devices may not scale in time. Exchanges built on Linux are another possible answer, but those are of course custodial and possibly also vulnerable to similar attacks.

I don't have all the answers, but I want to raise the question to get us to start thinking about it. It's possible that the answer here is in part social or political, not simply technological. 

[1]: https://t.co/k5bihogT8v
