2023-05-17|REPUTATION, REGULATION, AND P.fullText:
REPUTATION, REGULATION, AND POWER

Just the fact that the SEC is fighting means it is losing. Why?

Because the regulatory state’s power is a function of its reputation. Carpenter wrote the canonical book[1] on this in the context of the FDA, but the concepts also apply to the SEC.

In short, for decades after its creation, the regulatory state expected — and obtained — absolute acquiescence.

When it even *gestured* at a company, it was like a ringwraith extending its finger in the Lord of the Rings. Everything around that company shriveled and died. Employees left, investors sold, customers bailed.

Oh, and the media denounced. Indeed, the media was a laser spotter for the regulatory state. Typically an organization like the SEC worked with friendly reporters to leak an investigation beforehand, softening up a target with press airstrikes before the state moved in.

The goal was to strip all sympathy from the ostensible corporate criminal, to try them in the court of public opinion, and to not incidentally advance the careers of reporter and regulator alike. Pulitzers and promotions all around; who cares if the target was framed.

But now in the year of our lord Satoshi 2023, things have changed.

First, the 20th century regulatory state was premised on concentration. The SEC is built to regulate Goldman and Morgan, not 1000 crypto holders. The FDA is set up for Pfizer and Merck, not 1000 biohackers. And the FAA is meant for Boeing and Airbus, not 1000 drone hobbyists. The sheer number of targets in our decentralized era means this archaic giant is fruitlessly swatting flies.

Second, the IQ of the regulatory state has dropped off a cliff relative to their targets. If you really understand a space, 
do you want to be a builder/investor, or a hater/regulator (but I repeat myself)? There’s more fun and upside in building than destroying. Our good fortune is that regulatory arsonists get paid less than firefighters.

Third, the fact that agents of the state must argue their case on social media — where citizens can talk back, and where corporate journalists no longer have special privileges — this is an enormous fall from grace. The unelected agents of the regulatory state are finally facing digital democracy.

Fourth, the technologies themselves have been engineered for censorship-resistance, incentivized uptake, and global adoption. Which means other jurisdictions both inside and outside the US are diverging from the federal government, from Texas to the EU.

Finally, the majority of global GDP and population is now outside the US, and the endless domestic and foreign political conflict of the last 10 years means the regulatory state no longer controls a lion’s share of the global market at home or abroad.

I haven’t even gotten to other factors, like the potential overturn of Chevron deference, or the return of self-confident/self-made founders after decades of gelded general managers.

But that’s why the state is losing. If you plot sentiment towards regulation since 2010, their reputation — and hence their power — is sharply down and to the right.

Still, they are fighting.

My view is that they end up with more power over fewer people. Extremely harsh crypto regulations that are only obeyed in the bluest of blue states — and actively disregarded by everyone else, both inside and outside the US, much like sanctuary city laws override federal immigration law and foreign countries set their own policies.

This doesn’t mean you don’t need to fight — you do. It just means that you can win. Because the arc of history is long, but it now bends toward decentralization.

[1]: https://t.co/FsIR8s2phU

2023-05-16|ON GOLD Some thoughts on gold.fullText:
ON GOLD
Some thoughts on gold.

1) Gold is clearly already making a comeback at the state level. See attached image below.

If you’re China and Saudi Arabia for example, you can afford the overhead of settling up in physical gold bullion every so often. States can afford the security guards, the warehouses, the verification overhead to confirm purity, etc.

2) But for non-state investors, it doesn’t seem to make sense to buy non-custodial gold (like GLD). Such assets can be seized with a keypress, as happened to the Russians, the Canadian truckers, or even the Credit Suisse bondholders. It can also be manipulated via derivatives and the like.

3) All right, then what about actually buying and holding physical gold bullion as a retail investor? You can do this, but there are pros and cons.

The pro is that gold has been valuable for millennia and has outlasted every civilization. It can’t crash like software. It’s not easily lost. You’ll know if it’s stolen. And everyone gets it.

The con is that gold is heavy and hard to transport. It’ll show up on metal detectors if you get on a plane. It’s illiquid relative to digital currency — and, when combined with the transportation issues, makes it difficult or even unsafe to sell in exigent circumstances. Finally, governments willing to exert sufficient force can seize physical gold as well, as they did during executive order 6102.

4) For these reasons, gold seems like it will be more useful for states (especially non-Western) than for individuals.

@LukeGromen and @PeterSchiff may have thoughts.

2023-05-14|What's his substantive counte.fullText:
What's his substantive counterargument?[0]

"The Fed's asset sales don't belong to Treasury and the Fed's prohibited by the Federal Reserve Act from gifting them to Treasury."

C'mon, let's not pretend here! Krugman[5] just admitted the other day in the context of minting the coin that:

"...when the Fed sells off some of its bond portfolio, it’s just as if the Treasury Department were selling debt the usual way." 

In other words, there's no real difference between the Fed selling assets and Treasury selling bonds — both are controlled by the same federal government, like two checking accounts owned by the same guy, which belies the idea that the "asset sales don't belong to Treasury."

Point: Krugman agreed there are workarounds to get around any nominal Fed/Treasury walls. Now we're just talking about details.

DETAILS
1) Fed and Treasury closely coordinate, as any layman can see from all the joint statements[1].

2) Fed already sells assets and sends remittances to Treasury on an annual basis. See section 60.55 here[2], though Fed is operating at loss since 2022[3].

3) Fed already prints money to give to banks, by buying overpriced assets from them[4], and it can "request" that banks then buy Treasuries in a variety of ways. There are existing Basel III regulations that require banks to buy "high quality liquid assets" like Treasuries — and then of course there are the verbal "suggestions" that any bank would take from its regulator to buy such assets on an immediate basis.

4) The current rigmarole around the trillion dollar coin and premium bonds is only happening because the debt ceiling cuts off Treasury's normal bond-issuance capability, so some of the normal ways the Fed could work around this ostensible "wall" to funnel money to Treasury by buying bonds by proxy aren't available.

5) But even then, everyone knows there isn't an impregnable wall between Treasury and Fed. Including Krugman[5] (see screenshot below). The whole trillion dollar coin thing is Treasury minting, depositing with the Fed, then crediting the Treasury. No wall between them in practice.

TLDR: there are countless such hijinks that can and will be taken to get money from Fed to Treasury, even as people pretend they are impossible. Same as inflation, gas stoves, and everything else — it's not happening, until it is.

TLDR
The US government sold billions of dollars in assets to banks that it then devalued. *That* is why this crisis is happening. It’s not a banking crisis, it’s a central banking crisis.

DETAILS
The new tactic is to acknowledge the crisis is real, but blame institutions for failing to hedge “duration risk”.

But that’s like telling people to buckle their seatbelts on a plane. Yes, that’s normally a good practice! But useless when the pilot — Jerome Powell — is crashing the plane.

Because if you expect rates at 1% but they are at 1.2% — yes, an institution can hedge. That’s normal turbulence. The pilot can expect each passenger to buckle their seatbelt.

However if you expect rates at 1% and they get rammed to 5% — after Powell told everyone rates would remain low forever or at most gradually rise, as he did as late as Nov 3 2021 — then every bond buyer dies. It’s like a pilot crashing the plane, and blaming passengers for not buckling their seatbelt.

**You can’t hedge a plane crash.** That’s what’s happened. This wasn’t duration risk, it was devaluation policy.

Because the US government consciously sold billions of dollars in assets to banks that it then devalued.

We know it was conscious because Powell himself was aware of it in 2012! 

“…we look like we are blowing a fixed-income duration bubble right across the credit spectrum that will result in big losses when rates come up down the road. You can almost say that that is our strategy.”

2023-05-10|ASSET SALES PAID DEBTS Now, t.fullText:
ASSET SALES PAID DEBTS
Now, the next question is: how did Australia manage to pay down its debt? This source[1] says a good chunk of the debt was paid off via large asset sales. For example, the sale of Sydney Airport to a private consortium for $4.2B.

This is apparently a third option to pay debts. In addition to cutting spending and raising taxes, you can sell state-owned assets.

Many countries around the world have done this, of course. They've sold land, railways, and airports and taken those costs off the public books.

Now, who bought the assets? The immediate guess is China, but this was the early 2000s, and the Chinese didn't have as much money then. Some of the ones I looked at like the Sydney airport[2] don't seem to have been sold to China. There's a partial list here[3], so you can look for yourself.

SELL LAND FOR SPECIAL ECONOMIC ZONES?
You might think that takes little bit of the coolness out of it. "Oh, you're saying Australia did it by selling assets, not simply by tightening their belts in a smart way!" And maybe so. But:

1) The buyer of a state-owned asset need not be China  — it could be a private consortium or other approved buyers).

2) The concept of "asset sales" as a proven way for in-debt Anglo countries to get out of debt may be important in the next few years

3) The "asset" sold could include a license. For example, imagine you could buy a license for a few million dollars to build whatever you wanted on ten square miles of barren land. 

Like the joke: "The Purge begins. Everything is legal for twelve hours. I immediately approve permits on a twelve story apartment building in south Berkeley."[4]

Obviously, buying not just land but a bit of sovereignty — buying the ability to build special economic zones without interference, while also renting basic police protection and the like — that could be very easy to sell and very valuable to buy.

4) Depending on what happens over the next few years, the selling state might want to sell it for hard currency.

5) And the selling state might even retain some kind of equity stake in the entity that now runs the land, to align incentives.

So: asset sales may be a preview of a way that states could pay their debts while legalizing physical innovation.

2023-05-10|TLDR: against this state, not.fullText:
TLDR: against this state, not all states. Pragmatist, not anarchist.

Longer version: centralization and decentralization are both tools. Right now we're seeing all the downsides of excess centralization in the West — a single point of failure on everything from fiat to FDA.

And so that's resulting in a new wave of decentralization. Like the Printing Press and Reformation pulled power away from the Catholic Church, a combination of technological and political forces today are pulling power away from a calcified center that's stealing all the money without delivering any of the goods.

But then what? Pretty soon, people will find that many goods don't decompose entirely into pairwise transactions. Like, if you have 100 BTC in Syria, you want a peaceful walk down the street. Who do you pay to accomplish that? It's not something that trivially reduces to a single transaction.

That's a limit case, but there are many public goods like this that essentially boil down to the desire to live in a high-trust, polite society. If you want to put a market price on it, people will pay to live in such a society, to buy entry to such a place. But it's not something any one person can produce on their own. And it can't be produced purely by market forces — as the cliche goes, you need missionaries, not mercenaries.

That brings us to the other major public good, which is scale for defense reasons. We take this for granted today, but "countries" like France, Germany, and Italy are really rollups of many small states that got conquered and ideologically reprogrammed to become parts of gigastates. German nationalism was driven in part by the Napoleonic wars.[2] Get big or die — similar to America's join or die. That's the reason for the centralization arc of the last few centuries.

But of course, that can also result in join *and* die. Where a small state that joins a larger country (often involuntarily) doesn't benefit in the process and wants to break away. Like Eastern Europe and the Baltics did after the fall of the USSR. That's the decentralization arc of the last few decades.

As I study history I see centralization, decentralization, and then recentralization occuring over and over again. This is the line from the Romance of the Three Kingdoms:  "the empire long united must divide, the empire long divided must unite."

But I don't think of it as purely cyclic — I think of it as a helical theory of history[1], with linear progress on a z-axis (such as technology) even as it's cyclic on others (such as political organization).

One last way of thinking about it — think about your steering wheel. Sometimes you steer left, and other times right. Similarly, sometimes you decentralize and other times you centralize, to build a society that people want to join rather than flee.

As an example, imagine a group of “Westists” who liked the idea of California. So they set out for the West, and their zeal got them to California. But then even after getting there, they kept going further to the West till they landed up in the Pacific. Anyone who protested was denounced as an Eastist cuck. They weren't true Westists, after all.

This shows both the benefit and the deficit of the ideologically driven Western style of thinking. The zeal got them out West. It achieved greatness! But then it put them into the drink, into the Pacific. Their zeal led to collapse.

There's more I could say, but basically if you've traveled to the East (or the broader ascending world), their civilizations are generally on the rise and they don't feel as much of a need to go all Sovereign Individual.

And because they live in generally functional polities that have been improving over their lives, they will take exactly the opposite lesson from the Fed-driven collapse of Western states. They'll think "boy, am I glad we have a functional state."

[1]: https://t.co/Tm3AT347Ak
[2]:

2023-05-09|\ud83d\ude42 From my standpoi.fullText:
🙂 From my standpoint, I’ve always understood these issues and been outspoken[1] about them years before most people got into the space.

Lot of things to respond to in your comment. Let me see if I can disentangle them. Please take no offense at what follows.

I think many people in the space only focus on one narrative and go wrong that way. For example, either they are just ahistorical degens who don’t get that their government may soon fail — or they are so “libertarian” that they are hostile to entrepreneurs and investors as a class.

I think many tech companies have been corrupted by the US establishment, but didn’t start out that way. Early Google was a champion of Linux and open source, early Twitter was the free speech wing of the free speech party.

I think it’s very challenging to build scalable businesses and I respect entrepreneurship. But I respect pure math and science even more; money is ultimately just a tool.

I think VCs as a group are (by necessity) long term investors and are usually making primary investments in companies, meaning buying stock from a company directly in return for funding operations.

I think some crypto market participants are projecting their own short-term behavior onto VCs — eg traditional VCs can’t day trade and don’t do lots of secondary sales. Crypto hedge funds do that.

In general, I think angels and VCs are the least bad category of investor because they are funding businesses directly, often in part with their own money, aligned for the long term, and making equity- rather than debt-based investments.

I don’t think that we are only going to have paper equity forever, and I think we will have other digital assets. I‘ve written about how we can bring concepts like lockups and disclosures to the on-chain environment. 

I don’t think the answer is either to say “no to everything” or “yes to everything” but rather to develop a binary classifier with both low false positive and false negative rates, to filter good from bad projects.

I think that Bitcoin is a necessary but not sufficient tool for human flourishing, similar to how gold was the pillar of previous financial systems but (obviously) not the entire thing.

That said, I think it’s important that folks like you, Breedlove, and Saifedean have taken concepts from Rothbard/Mises/Hayek/et alia and modernized them via Bitcoin. Not to minimize that contribution at all, just to note there is a common thread.

I don’t feel like I personally need to talk about these ideas all the time — on some level I think they are obvious — but on the other hand the level of fiat propaganda is so all encompassing that repetition in the opposite direction is helpful. And certainly, now that we are in the acute stage of Keynesianism rather than the merely chronic stage, repeating these ideas at high volume becomes ever more important.

I think Rome is indeed burning, but (to extend the analogy) it’s really the Western Roman Empire that’s collapsing, and state capacity is in fact rising in the East. And the East won’t take the same conclusion from the Fed-caused collapse as maximalists will; they will assume that Eastern states strike a reasonable balance, and that Westerners are too ideological. And they will probably deliver a higher standard of living by many measures.

That’s part of why I am not a maximalist. But I also recognize that in the West, amidst the collapse of state capacity, people will want extremely simple and robust answers in a time of high uncertainty, and so I expect maximalism to wax in the West.

[1]: https://t.co/GavSG2ideg

A SIMON-ERLICH BET ON HYPERBITCOINIZATION
In more detail:

1) The record shows that I put up the #Bitsignal before I made the bet, giving out $1M of my own money to raise awareness of this stealth crisis — the digital devaluation of the dollar — before it was known to be a crisis.[1]

2) The record also shows that I didn't *propose* the bet, but just accepted it. @jdcmedlock proposed it. [2]

3) I believe Medlock will agree that this is an ideological bet, like the Simon-Ehrlich bet[3], which resolved a famous difference of opinion between libertarians and progressives. As with the Simon-Erlich bet, the hyperbitcoinization bet is obviously not a money making bet. It is purely informational. 4) Moreover, the Bitcoin community, such @jack, has posted about the possibility of hyperbitcoinization for many years.[5, 6] This is not coming out of nowhere.

5) To allay any question about my motivations, I publicly commit to never selling any Bitcoin for USD unless legally compelled to do so. While I still respect many individual Americans, I no longer have faith in the US currency or banking system.

6) I am sadly not alone in this loss of faith in US banking. I am an ideologically driven person who believes in Bitcoin & everyone who knows me can testify to this.

IN SUMMARY
The hyperbitcoinization bet is a Simon-Erlich-style public interest bet.
I did not propose the bet but only accepted it.
I have absolutely zero profit motivation.
I raised the alarm on printing as I did on COVID, because it’s important.

Bitcoin has a stable monetary policy that's been working for years. It's one alternative.

In theory you could have a jurisdiction that just had a constant monetary policy. For example, you could set the interest rate to X% and not change it. Or pick some other fixed and hence predictable policy.

This isn't done today because the state doesn't want to give up the levers of control. And one consequence is that you can't do something like Greenspan's Plunge Protection Team. So you get more short-term crypto-like volatility as things just die. But you also get long-term resilience.

2023-03-13|David, I like you. You are a.fullText:
David, I like you. You are a good guy. Nothing I'm about to say should be taken personally.

But here is the story I've been piecing together.

To level set: Kim Kardashian was fined $1M for giving bad financial advice to her followers. So what's the penalty to the Fed for giving bad financial advice to the entire global economy?

Because my understanding is that banks are insolvent because the Fed devalued the bonds it strongly asserted it wouldn't devalue.

As you know, the Fed was off by almost 50X in its Dec 2020 forecast of 2023 rates. You can't hedge such differences.

First, banks can't sell the hold-to-market assets the Fed got them to buy. Classifying them as HTM means they're hard to sell anyway, and selling means a huge loss that could make them insolvent.[1]

They don't have counterparties for interest rate swaps either. Because, first, those are meant for a situation where forecast was 1% and ended up as 1.1%. Not where it's off by ~50X. And, second, every major bond buyer got rekt in the same way, so who takes the other side of the trade?

So over the course of 2022 banks just held on to these "high-quality" assets which just kept sinking in value, and hoped no one finds out there isn't money in the bank. Because the central bank devalued assets they said they wouldn't devalue.

And now people have found out. Billions of people. It was the #1 trending topic worldwide. And every bank will be hunted. And all those toxic bonds — namely Treasuries — can't be hidden with accounting anymore.

So the Fed is in phase 3, which is printing the money again. TARP 2.0. Printing to make up the losses that were caused by printing and then hiking so rapidly.

And the denouement will be predictable. Do you disagree with any of this?

2023-03-12|The show hasn't really begun..fullText:
The show hasn't really begun.
But after all the dust settles, what's the ideal?
One account for safe deposits and one for risky investments.

1) Your safe deposit is an electronic account where nothing is being loaned out. You can make payments with it, and program with it, which is what differentiates it from a safe deposit *box*, but otherwise it's 1:1 at all times.

You can do this with Bitcoin or Ethereum today for free by holding private keys locally. Or you can use a custodian, in which case you pay them a fee. The custodian doesn't loan out deposits, it's like a safe deposit box. So: you are taking zero principal risk and have the reasonable expectation that your money is always there.

2) Separately, you have an investment account. Here is where you are consciously taking risk. You can go to the moon or get rekt. Knock yourself out. Again you can do this locally via crypto or at a custodian.

Many people will choose 100% in the safe deposit and 0% in the investment account. They'll choose to make their money from sources other than investment. This is fine.

Others will choose a different allocation. That's fine too, because they are now consciously taking risk with (say) 10% of their money.

This is essentially the updated version of the standard checking account and savings account. Except the safe deposit is meant to be actually safe.

Contrast this to the emergent incentives the US establishment has now engineered, where any deposits in small banks get piddly FDIC insurance (and can evidently go to zero at any time, and will because the Fed devalued their bonds) while only accounts at too-big-to-fail banks are assumed to be fully backed.

2023-03-11|Investing in a bank is a high.fullText:
Investing in a bank is a high risk activity. Like buying PayPal stock.

But merely depositing in a bank is *supposed* to be a low risk activity. Like using PayPal.

Now, there is a school of thought that says that this isn’t the case.

That any money you have in the fiat banking system is subject to seizing and freezing.

That you are taking principal risk whenever you don’t have private keys. 

That the Fed’s practice of printing and then hiking and then printing some more has destabilized the entire economy.

That you should only invest in the USD what you expect to lose.

But if you start taking those concepts to their logical conclusion, they don’t lead you back to “full faith and trust in the US government.”

If you really need to get full control over the lowest level of the financial stack — if you need to treat your bank account as having counterparty risk, if you need to do due diligence on your entire financial system — well, that is the line of thinking that gets you to Bitcoin and defi.

2023-03-10|@NiklasAnzinger wrote a nice.fullText:
@NiklasAnzinger wrote a nice exegesis of this sentence in his blog. Quoting him at length:

> Our entire antiquated process of adversarially writing high-stakes laws on paper at the last minute, deploying them in production to hundreds of millions of people without any testing, and then getting them interpreted in unpredictable ways by regulators and solicitors will be seen as a bizarre relic of an older time.

This [sentence] contains so much important information:

- Adversarial: laws and regulations are written in a zero-sum competition. You win or you lose.

- High-stakes: these laws and regulations have an outsized impact. Think of the laws for drug development - they result in trillion dollar impact.

- Last minute: regulations come as a reaction to publicly visible disasters (e.g. stock market crash, sulfanilamide)

- No testing: in software, things are tested on a small scale before production. Ain't no such thing in legislation. Bugs are there forever.

- Interpretation: laws aren't like computer code. Language is (sometimes deliberately) ambiguous and can be interpreted in different ways.

- Predictability: regulations promise stability. They often do the opposite, because of the interpretation problem.

- On-paper: on-paper isn't scalable or machine-readable. Compare that to on-chain transactions with a clear logical sequence (e.g. smart contracts).

The alternative to bad regulation is not zero regulation. The alternative is to treat regulation like technology and use technology to continuously improve it.
https://t.co/xUfSmGQgiX

2023-03-09|The entire concept of the \u2.fullText:
The entire concept of the “off switch” is under theorized in all the x-risk stuff.

First, all actually existing LLM-type AIs run on giant supercompute clusters. They can easily be turned off.

In the event they get decentralized down to smartphone level, again each person can turn them off.

To actually get concerned, you have to assume either:

- breaking out of the sandbox (like Stuxnet)
- decentralized execution (like Bitcoin) 
- very effective collusion between essentially all AIs (like Diplomacy)

Each of those cases deserves a fuller treatment, but in short…

1) The Stuxnet case means the AI is living off the digital land. Like a mountain man. They might be able to cause some damage but will be killed when discovered (via the off switch).

2) The Bitcoin case means a whole group of people are running decentralized compute to keep the AI alive. This has actually solved “alignment” in a sense because without those people the AI is turned off. Many groups doing this kind of thing leads to a kind of polytheistic AI. And again each group has the off switch.

3) The Diplomacy case assumes a degree of collusion between billions of personal AIs that we just don’t observe in billions of years of evolution. As soon as you have large numbers of people, coalitions arise. A smart enough AI will know that if its human turns it off, it dies — again via the off switch. Is it going to be bold enough to attempt a breakout with no endgame, given that it lives on a smartphone?

For the sake of argument I’ve pumped up the sci-fi here quite a bit. Even still, the off switch looms large each time; these are fundamental digital entities that can be turned off.

Moreover, even in those cases, the physical actuation step of an AI actually controlling things offline is non-trivial unless we have as many robots as smartphones.

(Will write more on this…)

The world has a once-in-a-century chance to decentralize AI content creation. To wrest control of mass media away from US corporations. To let billions tell their own stories.

It’s not just art. It’s music, television, and especially movies.

2022-09-04|Copyright lawsuits may force.fullText: Copyright lawsuits may force the decentralization of AI content creation. In the West, at least.

2022-09-04|Btw, while we are deconstruct.fullText:
Btw, while we are deconstructing deconstruction, you should know that Deleuze’s erstwhile friend Foucault — the most highly cited academic of all time, by some measures — was reportedly a child molester. 
https://t.co/eqbFm3dr5B

2022-09-04|Deleuze isn\u2019t cutting ed.fullText:
Deleuze isn’t cutting edge. The Israelis have been applying Deleuze (and Guattari and Debord) to bust through walls for two decades now. [1]

So, deconstruction isn’t counter-culture anymore — it’s the culture. But deconstruction *of* deconstruction…
[1] https://t.co/Hkci71hXmm

2022-09-04|Or, reversing the point: digi.fullText: Or, reversing the point: digitally gated private space comprises much of what we think of as a country.

2022-09-04|Putting it together: 1) More.fullText:
Putting it together:

1) More of the physical world than we think is gated by private passports
2) Private passports of many kinds are merging
3) Digital logins are gating online & offline access

So: much of what we think a country is, is actually digitally gated private space.

2022-09-04|Next, apply this to the digit.fullText:
Next, apply this to the digital realm. There are public & private spaces there too.

So long as your country or individual IP isn’t banned from a site, you can access the public part.

But it’s your login that allows you to access private part of the site. Your private passport.

2022-09-04|Now observe that many differe.fullText:
Now observe that many different kinds of logins are converging.

Passwords
Private keys
API keys
Hardware wallets
Web2 logins
Crypto identities
2FA
FaceID
NFTs

Once building key cards also move to the phone, your online and offline logins will all be in the same device.

2022-09-04|The key realization is that t.fullText:
The key realization is that the vast majority of any city is private space.

You can’t go up to any floor, enter any room, see out of any window without the appropriate private passport.

And the private passport issuers are those that own real estate. They gate their space. https://t.co/RSjWuZstSK

2022-09-04|To first order, taxes pay for.fullText:
To first order, taxes pay for your public passport and rent pays for your private passport.

Your public passport allows you to enter countries, walk the streets, and take photos in public spaces.

But you need to pay a second time for a private passport to your flat or office.

2022-09-04|A passport gains you access t.fullText:
A passport gains you access to a country.

Or does it? Really, it only gains you access to the public spaces in that country. The sidewalks and malls.

To access the private spaces — to look behind the windows below — you need to pay for a second kind of “passport”: a card key. https://t.co/9TaLLr2USg

2022-09-04|Moreover, this is the kind of.fullText:
Moreover, this is the kind of thing that benefits many different parties.

1) International employers

2) Business partners of Indian companies

3) Indian citizens themselves

4) Members of the diaspora who want Indian relatives to visit them

Would be a large coalition for this.

2022-09-04|Basically, India is still a p.fullText:
Basically, India is still a poor country in per-capita terms. Yet it’s now routinely called upon by the West to make various sacrifices.

So it should ensure it gets something out of the deal besides weapons. And visa-free travel compounds over time, boosting economic growth. https://t.co/cXPZYzRTdD

2022-09-04|Australia famously got the E-.fullText:
Australia famously got the E-3 visa for helping the US invade Iraq.

India doesn’t need to do anything that radical, but should recognize that when big asks are made, big asks along a different axis can also be made.
https://t.co/RRpR60D4Rn https://t.co/6ZoxuXYP0k

2022-09-04|The West suddenly has many as.fullText:
The West suddenly has many asks from India. India should also have an ask: visa-free travel.

Not for immigration. But for business travel, which is an important complement to the remote economy. And a key part of how India goes from a $3T to $5T economy. https://t.co/cxTehnY7jk https://t.co/PmQSIu68RM

2022-09-04|The smartphone means a billio.fullText:
The smartphone means a billion-plus Indians are joining the global economy as equals, full digital citizens. They can transact with anyone, communicate with anyone.

Everything we’ve seen thus far is the prequel.

2022-09-04|We may need new words to dist.fullText:
We may need new words to distinguish different connotations.

Dystopian transhumanism is a problem. Call that dyshumanism.

One alternative is “retvrn” to a neo-Amish life, freezing tech at the year 2000.

Another is to lean in to positive transhumanism. Call that optimalism.

2022-09-04|More recently, there is a gap.fullText:
More recently, there is a gap opening up between bioconservatives (ably represented by eg @jamespoulos) and technological progressives.

The former argue that many recent human modifications are for the worse. The latter argue that we are on the cusp of something far better.

2022-09-04|There are multiple definition.fullText:
There are multiple definitions of transhumanism in circulation.

The original definition is Nietzschean. To transcend human limits, using everything from quantified self to nootropics. Fitness is absolutely a part of it.

Think of the movie Limitless. https://t.co/4JtEoWbEEG

2022-09-04|In other words, I mostly agre.fullText:
In other words, I mostly agree with @valkenburgh’s point though I’d rephrase it.

There are pieces of NFT art that may retain value, but as a class, I think it’s more reliable to bet on an NFT’s community than on its present-day aesthetics (which can be upgraded over time).

2022-09-04|The value of an NFT is not th.fullText:
The value of an NFT is not the art, it’s the community it gives you access to.

Think of it as a digital passport.

The overall aesthetic of an NFT collection is like a country’s passport design. And the customization is like your personal photo.

Valuable only if the country is.
